onboarding.intro: This tool helps you understand the structure of the Greek text before studying individual words.
onboarding.steps: I'll show you the key elements in 5 quick steps.
onboarding.skipTip: üí° You can skip this tutorial at any time
onboarding.step1Content: Read this blue box first. It gives you the complete overview of the passage's argument.
onboarding.step2Content1: Clauses with blue background are the main ones - the backbone of the text.
onboarding.step2Content2: Identify the main verb (position indicated below) and the subject.
onboarding.step3Content1: Indented clauses depend on the main clause.
onboarding.step3Content2: The color tells you its function: green (purpose), orange (cause), etc.
onboarding.step3Question: Question: "How does this clause modify the main clause?"
onboarding.step4Content: Use these buttons to control what you see:
onboarding.step4Collapse: Collapse All: Only main clauses (for overview)
onboarding.step4Tip: üí° Start collapsed to avoid being overwhelmed
onboarding.step5Content1: Each color represents a clause type with a specific function.
onboarding.step5Content2: For example: Green = Purpose ("so that..."), Orange = Cause ("because...")
onboarding.step5Done: ‚úÖ Ready! Now you know how to use syntactic analysis.

morphology.analysisTitle: Analysis of the components that form this Greek word
morphology.tipContent: When identifying morphemes, always start with the root (the main meaning), then analyze the prefixes that modify the sense, and finally the endings that indicate grammatical function. This order will help you understand both the meaning and the function of the word in the text.
